Currently we only show a `x` for clearing input. I don't want to use system folder picker. Would be great if there's a button to add that folder to current workspace.

title: Add an API for extensions to resolve variables in launch.json during resolveDebugConfiguration()

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
our debugger extension is going to parse a configuration and propagate the debug requests to language-specific debugger extensions (`vscode-python`, `vscode-cpptools`). 

for example, for the following configuration
```json
{
    "name": "debug",
    "type": "newtype",
    "request": "launch",
    "target": "${file}"
},
```
the target `${file}` points to an XML file that contains the actual launch requests. We need to actually parse that file and generate debug requests to the other debuggers.

Since we need access to `vscode.debug.startDebugging()`, this needs to take place inside `vscode.DebugConfigurationProvider.resolveDebugConfiguration()` (not the debug adapter). For this reason, we need an API to resolve VS Code variables manually (inside the extension's context).

title: Hang on rendering markup or markdown
body:
Issue Type: Bug Scenario 1: viewing extension information 1. Open Extensions View 2. Select any extension 3. The extension details page hangs indefinitely Scenario 2: viewing markdown preview 1. Open a markdown file 2. Click 'Open Preview to the Side' 3. Preview tab hangs indefinitely Scenario 3: launch liveshare session 1. Open Live Share View 2. Click 'Start collaboration session...' 3. Live Share Intro page hangs indefinitely Things I have tried: 1. Updated to latest version 2. Disabling all extensions and reseting to factory settings 3. Completely removing vscode and all related files from my machine and reinstalling 4. Same steps in latest 'Insiders' build - Version: 1.38.0-insider - Commit: c8d44e24dd250d416475a10efe64e35c9e2c65b3 5. Opened Developer Tools and watch console - unfortunately there is no new output before it hangs I have another MacBook Pro that doesn't have the same problem. title: Feature Request: Allow passing args inside entries of Npm Scripts Explorer
body:
<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
If you have an npm script that requires passing arguments to the binary being ran, normally the way you would pass args would be:
` npm run script -- -a -b `
However, running scripts through Npm Scripts Explorer would yield an error, since additional arguments are missing.

## Suggestion
Maybe we can have an additional action when right-clicking a script entry that will allow us to append args.
![npm_args](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16144679/63351481-56e05d80-c32d-11e9-8060-ca257f16bc56.png)

title: FR: Generate custom cheat sheets
body:
TL;DR: Consider allowing to locally generate keyboard cheat sheet PDFs with the currently used shortcuts from within vscode.

It's nice to have beautifully designed cheat sheets for the keaboard shortcuts (#14071).

Unfortunately they neither take into account localization nor customization.
So while for the former it would be great if you provided PDFs for the default keymaps for the most prevalent keyboard layouts on your website (not just en-us), the more general solution this ticket is about is to allow vscode to _locally_ create PDFs with the current keyboard settings, if that's not too much of a overhead technically.

While this might open the gates for further requests like picking other commands' shortcuts to be displayed on the cheat sheet or reordering or regrouping the commands or redesigning the sheet itself, I assume it's a perfectly reasonable middle ground to enable users to just generate the very same cheat sheet with the very same design, set of commands, grouping, ordering etc, but taking into account the shortcuts actually set by the user.

title: Code actions are not reset after application
body:
### Build

```
Version: 1.37.1
Commit: f06011ac164ae4dc8e753a3fe7f9549844d15e35
Date: 2019-08-15T16:16:34.800Z
Electron: 4.2.7
Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
Node.js: 10.11.0
V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0
OS: Darwin x64 18.7.0
```

### Description

I'm working on a language server that lints user code. The server returns code actions for various issues. I noticed that if a user chooses to apply a code action (for example, that deletes a line), the editor doesn't clear the diagnostic, or ask the server again for updated code actions. This results in the user being able  to apply the code fix again and again, deleting more valid lines.

### Steps to Reproduce:

I've wrote a small repro [here](https://github.com/OmarTawfik/vscode-extension-samples/commit/050a3ce18b3def49c3f551e07e8472fbd21ac891). Simply open the extension and run using `Client + Server` launch configuration.
The sample provides code actions to delete duplicate empty lines. The user is able to delete more valid lines by re-applying the code action. Here is also a video of this happening:

![code-action-repro (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15987992/63326726-b0bb3600-c2e1-11e9-9f2f-0dc0884009ce.gif)

Unless there is something wrong with the sample server implementation, the editor shouldn't allow applying the same code action twice to the same document, as it produces invalid contents.

title: autoAttachChildProcesses attaching to external threads
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38.0-insider
- OS Version: Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS
- Dev Runtime: NodeJs v10.16.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. configure two nodejs cluster based applications with multiple child threads and open them in two seperate instances of vscode.
2. create a launch debug profile configured with "autoAttachChildProcesses": true for both projects.
3. start both debug sessions sequentially
4. you will find that the first debug session will have attached to the second debug session child threads and also breakpoints that are set in one session are being hit in the alternate session.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Links in markdown are broken if url contains encoded parameters
body:
Issue Type: Bug In the latest VSCode release (1.37.0) there seems to be a regression in markdown rendering feature, in that some of the URL parameters are incorrectly getting encoded . Repro steps 1. Create a markdown file and put following url content in it and save the file: ``` [Sample Link](https://myhost.com/Redirect?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bing.com%3Fsearch%3Dtom) ``` 2. Click this link in markdown, see that the URL that is passed to browser is: https://myhost.com/Redirect?url=http://www.bing.com%253Fsearch=tom Notice that the %3F in the _url_ parameter in the markdown link has been further encoded into %253F Expected: The URL that is passed to browser is either for the two below 1. https://myhost.com/Redirect?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bing.com%3Fsearch%3Dtom 2. https://myhost.com/Redirect?url=http://www.bing.com?search=tom This issue is true for other surfaces of markdown as well, like the 'Details' tab of installed extensions and the hover popup set through text decorations, via the vscode.DecorationOptions class. This issue does not repro in older version of VSCode (1.36.0 and prior). title: Render whitespace characters not monospaced when italicized
body: Issue Type: Bug I'm using Roboto Mono as my editor font. I have all 8 styles installed (e.g. Regular, Italic, ...) In my theme, C++ comments are italicized. I turned on the new `"editor.renderWhitespace": "selection"` setting and find that when selecting a line with comments (italicized text), the character used for space is not the same width as a normal space. This has the rather jarring effect of moving the text around while selecting. Is this an issue with the font? What is the specific character used to denote space with "render whitespace"? VS Code version: Code 1.37.1 (f06011ac164ae4dc8e753a3fe7f9549844d15e35, 2019-08-15T16:17:55.855Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134 Remote OS version: Linux x64 3.10.0-957.5.1.el7.x86_64

title: High CPU Usage When Accessing .NET Webforms Project on Windows SMB Share
body:
Issue Type: Bug On a MacBook Pro '16: 1. Connect to Windows Shared Drive through SMB 2. Add .NET Webforms Project to VS Code Window 3. Watch Computer Possibly Explode - High CPU usage causes terrible slow downs, sometimes WindowsServer restarts. **Note:** I disabled extensions before reporting this issue. It still occurs. It's something I've had issues with since VS Code was first released. It's also not consistent. Sometimes things are fine for a brief period of time, then *something* happens and it starts eating CPU. Other times, like during my submitting this issue, it'll happen right away and then disappear after a period of time. But quite often, when it does happen, it ends up requiring me force quitting VS Code processes and trying again. Unfortunately, I can't supply any of the projects where this occurs due to copyright. But the sites are built on AspDotNetStorefront and hosted on a Windows 10 VM locally. It's not the smallest project but it's not really *that* large either. I have even ignored many directories hoping that will help - it doesn't appear to. Thanks for listening. title: Improve @import SCSS Navigate
body:
Hello, I just updated to the most recent vscode:

Version: 1.37.1 (system setup)
Commit: f06011ac164ae4dc8e753a3fe7f9549844d15e35
Date: 2019-08-15T16:17:55.855Z
Electron: 4.2.7
Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
Node.js: 10.11.0
V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

And it looks like in the release notes there was a message about improvement to the searched locations for @import scss statements.  This is a suggestion to provide additional support for ~ syntax.  In the app portion of my project, I have a generalized sass folder that holds common sass files for the application.  Throughout stylesheets in components, I reference these common sass files via imports using the ~ syntax to resolve the folder location regardless of the current depth of the component that calls these stylesheets:

@import '~app/sass/mixins';
@import '~app/sass/forms';

It would be nice if vscode was also be able to parse this as trying to navigate to the stylesheet yields an error:  

Unable to open 'mixins': Unable to read file (Error: File not found (d:\Projects\MyProjectName\MyAppName\Angular\src\app\component-name\component-name\component-name\component-name\app\sass\mixins)). (folder path replaced with generic names i.e. component-name, MyProjectName, and MyAppName for anonymity)

title: [Feature request] Add the possibility to define variables in launch.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
In the C++ plugin, you can define environment variables in the c_cpp_properties.json like so:


```
{
"env" : {
        "systemIncludePaths": [
            "/usr/include",
            "/usr/include/c++/5.4.0",
            "/usr/include/c++/5.4.0/backward",
            "/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu",
            "/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/c++/5.4.0",
            "/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/5/include",
            "/usr/lib/gcc/x86_64-linux-gnu/5/include-fixed",
            "/usr/local/include",
            "/usr/local/lib/clang/6.0.1/include"
        ]
}
// ...
}
```

They can then be used in the settings like this: `${env:systemIncludePaths}` or `${systemIncludePaths}`
I would like to be able to do this in launch.json as well to define program paths.
It would be great if this was possible in all .json settings files, actually, and to top it off, if env vars would work across settings files.

title: some korean translation is missing
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

title: Help webview extensions add a Content Security Policy
body:
Many webview extensions do not currently set a [content security policy](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP). All webviews (even very simple ones) should set a content security policy. This is not a immediate security problem but a content security policy helps to limit the potential impact of content injections and is generally a good measure for defense in depth. 

I've put together this initial list of extensions that create webviews that seem not to have a content security policy (there may be false positives). If you are feeling like a security hero, **consider helping these extensions out by submitting a PR that adds a restrictive content security policy to their webviews**. [Here's our documentation to help you get started](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/extension-guides/webview#content-security-policy).

Let me know if an extension has been fixed or was incorrectly flagged

---

**Key**

- - Confirmed and issue opened
-  - Fixed
-  - Can't confirm in current code in github master? 
- Blank - Unconfirmed

**Extensions**

-  vscjava.vscode-java-pack - https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-java-pack/issues/171

title: Accessibility: tabbing in an opened combobox sends the cursor to the first item in the document instead of next
body:
Environment Details:
Date: 2019-08-09T07:49:00.254Z
VS Code 1.37.0
Electron: 4.2.7
Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
Node.js: 10.11.0
V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code Settings, find a combobox (dropdown) and tab until it's focused.
2. Press spacebar or enter to open the dropdown.
3. Press Tab

Expected:
Combobox closes, focus moves to the next item in the tab hierarchy

Actual:
Focus moves to the first item in the UI (menus), I must tab all the way back to where I was.

Impact: accessibility/keyboard users

title: unlimited keyboard shortcut lengths

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: When setting up keyboard shortcuts, you are limited by a short pattern. it would be cool if you could set up your own combinations regardless of length (ctrl+alt+f s shift+alt+q). and that patterns recognize Enter as a key.

title: Debug console replaces newlines with spaces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Issue Type: Bug Message text sent to the debug console that includes newlines has them replaced with spaces. For example, `console.log(JSON.stringify({a:1,b:2,c:3}, null, 2))` emits: ``` undefined { "a": 1, "b": 2, "c": 3 } ``` Instead of e.g.: ``` undefined { "a": 1, "b": 2, "c": 3 } ``` Or even more trivially, `console.log("a\nb")` emits ``` undefined a b ``` Unpleasant workaround: `bigStringWithNewLines.split('\n')` and then expand out the array object in the console. VS Code version: Code 1.37.1 (f06011ac164ae4dc8e753a3fe7f9549844d15e35, 2019-08-15T16:17:25.463Z) OS version: Linux x64 4.19.0-5-amd64

title: Allow attaching/detaching from the debug targets

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
This request asks for a lightweight way of attaching/detaching the debugger UI to/from a debug target (in contrast to a heavyweight launch/attach that starts and ends a debug session).

If the debugger UI is detached (in the lightweight way), the debug session will continue to run and the debugger is still in control and can terminate the debuggee, but the debugger will not stop on breakpoints or exceptions because no debugging takes place.

In theory this could be implemented by means of DAP's "attach" and "disconnect" request: a DA is started and attaches to the debug target via the attach request. "Lightweight" detaching disconnects from the debug target via the disconnect request, but the debug adapter continues to run.

@pavelfeldman does this correctly reflect the intent of your item?

title: Preserve case for multi-cursor selections
body: In 1.37 there is case preservation feature for Find/Replace. It would be great if there would be such option for multi-cursor edit or at least for `editor.action.addSelectionToNextFindMatch` / `addSelectionToPreviousFindMatch` hotkeys.

title: Theming: settings checkboxes appear to be unaffected by customizations
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Apply dark theme
2. Apply customizations to settings checkboxes, for example:
```
        "settings.checkboxBackground": "#FFFFFF",
        "settings.checkboxForeground": "#009c00",
        "settings.checkboxBorder": "#404142",
```
3. Witness this:

![vscode-theming-settings](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37181601/63157960-212b3400-c010-11e9-98f8-057b9444f0ac.PNG)

As you can see, the border and background work, but the checkbox foreground color is different.

Either settings is using a different source for its colorization settings, or the official documentation on theming is wrong.
